Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - agitated, confused for most of the night, calmed minimally with IV
   Ativan x 1 @ 2AM
   - 5AM agitated again, both endorsing and denying chest pain, refusing
   all PO meds, EKG & unable to place leads secondary to agitation, vitals
   signs were stable & telemetry was unchanged, received 2mg IV Morphine &
   1mg IV Ativan with some improvement in agitation
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:

   Heparin Sodium - 850 units/hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Haloperidol (Haldol) - [**2182-1-22**] 04:56 PM

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:14.3/49.9/1.2, Ca++:8.9 mg/dL, Mg++:1.9
   mg/dL, PO4:3.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, transferred to CCU
   after aborted cardiac catheterization caused by agitation following an
   OSH ICU admission for respiratory failure & NSTEMI.
   .
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Currently, patient has a new
   stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. He is awaiting
   catheterization on [**1-24**] for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA
   occlusion. Currently, he is chest pain free, with negative CE
s, but
   refusing EKG.
   - ASA 325mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Plavix 75mg daily
   - Increase Metoprolol Tartrate to 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg TID when
   tolerating PO
   - Heparin gtt
   - No Integrillin given current Troponin
   - Morphine PRN: chest pain
   - Will continue to try and obtain EKG
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**]. Patient with persistent fluid overload
   on admission, but he was not pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac
   catheterization. On transfer, patient demonstrates mild respiratory
   distress and O2 requirement, limited clinical exam suggests fluid
   overload. Received IV Lasix on transfer with good UOP, but remains
   fluid overloaded this AM.
   - Repeat Lasix 40mg IV x 1 this AM, goal -1L today
   - O2 by NC
   - Increase Metoprolol Tartrate 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg TID when
   tolerating PO
   - Increase Lisinopril 5mg daily
   # Agitation/Mental status changes: Patient's cardiac catheterization
   aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to significant doses of
   Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital records, patient has
   been confused and agitated since his hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. He
   pulled out his Foley prior to transfer to the [**Hospital1 19**] and his wife
   reports that he was paranoid at [**Location (un) 755**], insisting that the FBI was out
   to get him. At home, however, his wife states that he is not confused,
   but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As patient has been
   attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is not fully
   oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary process
   appears to be agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium.
   Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may have some component
   of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - Psych consult, recommending Ativan 0.5 to 1mg IV q4H:PRN agitation,
   f/u additional recs
   - F/U folate, b12, TSH level this AM
   - Will try to avoid Haldol/Zyprexa as it will further prolong QT
   interval
   - 4 bed rail restraint
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes
   - Preserve sleep wake cycles
   - OOB for meals
   #. Rhythm: Patient in and out of AF in the CCU, but no report of h/o of
   AF. He has also been persistently tachycardic, despite having a regular
   rhythm on admission. This may be agitation paired with diuresis, but
   will continue to monitor closely.
   - On telemetry
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg PO TID when tolerating PO
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   - Gabapentin 600mg PO qHS
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN
   - SW consult
   #. HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
   #. HTN:
   -Continue Lisinopril 5mg daily
   -Continue Metoprolol Tartrate 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg PO TID if
   tolerating PO
   #. GERD:
   - Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.
   - Continue to observe
   #. Hx of TIA: Short-term left hand and leg weakness, now resolved. No
   focal neurologic deficits on admission.
   #. FEN: Cardiac/diabetic, MVI
   #. Access: Patient transferred with right subclavian line in place.
   Unable to pull line secondary to patient agitation, but will attempt to
   place PIV
s and will discontinue the subclavian line when PIV
s placed
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: cardiac/diabetic diet
   Glycemic Control:  NPH & Humalog sliding scale
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2182-1-22**] 03:15 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer: Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Patient
s wife [**Name (NI) 653**] [**Name (NI) 2064**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12871**]
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: pending cardiac catheterization on [**1-24**]

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

* The patient, an 82-year-old male, is in the ICU due to respiratory failure and NSTEMI. He has a history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, and was transferred to the ICU after an aborted cardiac catheterization due to agitation.
* The patient is currently experiencing agitation, confusion, and refusal of PO medications, which is likely due to a combination of factors including benzodiazepine withdrawal, dementia/delirium, and EtOH withdrawal.
* His cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation, and he has a new stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. He is awaiting further cardiac catheterization for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA occlusion.
* The patient has acute on chronic systolic CHF, and his fluid overload is being managed with IV Lasix.
* He is also experiencing respiratory distress and requires O2 therapy.
* The patient's labs show a troponin level of 0.04, and his EKG is pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation, and he has a new stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. He is awaiting further cardiac catheterization for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA occlusion. This increases the risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.
* Respiratory complications: The patient is experiencing respiratory distress and requires O2 therapy. This increases the risk of respiratory complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and respiratory failure.
* Neurological complications: The patient is experiencing agitation, confusion, and refusal of PO medications, which is likely due to a combination of factors including benzodiazepine withdrawal, dementia/delirium, and EtOH withdrawal. This increases the risk of neurological complications such as seizures, delirium, and cognitive impairment.
* Infection complications: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse and is at risk for infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of GERD and is at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, including his troponin level and EKG.
* Continue to manage his fluid overload with IV Lasix and monitor his urine output.
* Continue to provide O2 therapy and monitor his respiratory status closely.
* Continue to monitor his neurological status and manage his agitation and confusion with benzodiazepines as needed.
* Continue to monitor his infection risk and provide prophylactic antibiotics as necessary.
* Continue to monitor his gastrointestinal status and provide prophylactic medication for GERD as necessary.

I also recommend the following:

* Continue to educate the patient's family and caregivers on his condition and treatment plan.
* Continue to involve the patient's primary care physician in his care.
* Continue to monitor the patient's progress and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, and NSTEMI. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and NSTEMI, and his cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation. The patient has been experiencing agitation, confusion, and chest pain, which is concerning for unstable angina and NSTEMI.

The patient's current medical condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is stable, with a range of 100/66-161/86 mmHg. His heart rate is 95-116 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 33-40 breaths per minute.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula, and his SpO2 is 94%.
* Neurologic status: The patient is agitated and confused, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10-12. He is responding to verbal commands, but his movement and tone are not assessed.
* Laboratory results: The patient's troponin level is 0.04, and his creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL. His glucose level is 187 mg/dL, and his hemoglobin level is 13.0 g/dL.
* Medications: The patient is receiving a variety of medications, including IV antibiotics, anticoagulants, and antiplatelet agents.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Unstable angina or NSTEMI: The patient's chest pain and EKG changes suggest that he may be experiencing unstable angina or NSTEMI, which can lead to myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and his oxygen saturation is 94%, which may indicate respiratory failure.
* Seizures: The patient's agitation and confusion may increase his risk of seizures.
* Delirium: The patient's agitation and confusion may be indicative of delirium, which can be a complication of ICU care.
* Benzodiazepine withdrawal: The patient's history of EtOH abuse and his current use of benzodiazepines may increase his risk of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
* DVT: The patient's history of NSTEMI and his current use of anticoagulants may increase his risk of DVT.

To manage these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of cardiac instability, respiratory failure, and seizures. His medication regimen should be carefully adjusted to minimize the risk of benzodiazepine withdrawal and DVT.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, transferred to CCU
   after aborted cardiac catheterization caused by agitation following an
   OSH ICU admission for respiratory failure & NSTEMI.
   .
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Currently, patient has a new
   stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. He is awaiting
   catheterization on [**1-24**] for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA
   occlusion. Currently, he is chest pain free, with negative CE
s, but
   refusing EKG.
   - ASA 325mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Plavix 75mg daily
   - Increase Metoprolol Tartrate to 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg TID when
   tolerating PO
   - Heparin gtt
   - No Integrillin given current Troponin
   - Will continue to try and obtain EKG
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**]. Patient with persistent fluid overload
   on admission, but he was not pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac
   catheterization. On transfer, patient demonstrates mild respiratory
   distress and O2 requirement, limited clinical exam suggests fluid
   overload.
   - Lasix 40mg IV x 1, repeat PRN
   - O2 by NC
   - Increase Metoprolol Tartrate 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg TID when
   tolerating PO
   - Increase Lisinopril 5mg daily
   # Agitation/Mental status changes: Patient's cardiac catheterization
   aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to significant doses of
   Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital records, patient has
   been confused and agitated since his hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. He
   pulled out his Foley prior to transfer to the [**Hospital1 19**] and his wife
   reports that he was paranoid at [**Location (un) 755**], insisting that the FBI was out
   to get him. At home, however, his wife states that he is not confused,
   but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As patient has been
   attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is not fully
   oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary process
   appears to be agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium.
   Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may have some component
   of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - Psych consult, recommending Ativan 0.5 to 1mg IV q4H:PRN agitation
   - Will try to avoid Haldol/Zyprexa as it will further prolong QT
   interval
   - 4 bed rail restraint
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes
   - Preserve sleep wake cycles
   - OOB for meals
   #. Rhythm: Patient in and out of AF in the CCU, but no report of h/o of
   AF. He has also been persistently tachycardic, despite having a regular
   rhythm on admission. This may be agitation paired with diuresis, but
   will continue to monitor closely.
   - On telemetry
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg PO TID when tolerating PO
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   - Gabapentin 600mg PO qHS
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN
   - SW consult
   #. HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
   #. HTN:
   -Continue Lisinopril 5mg daily
   -Continue Metoprolol Tartrate 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg PO TID if
   tolerating PO
   #. GERD:
   - Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.
   - Continue to observe
   #. Hx of TIA: Short-term left hand and leg weakness, now resolved. No
   focal neurologic deficits on admission.
   #. FEN: Cardiac/diabetic, MVI
   #. Access: PIV, right subclavian line (will plan to d/c when patient
   cooperative)
   #. PPx: Heparin gtt
   #. Communication: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2064**] [**Known lastname 12865**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12866**]
   #. Code: FULL
   #. Dispo: pending repeat cardiac catheterization

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of CABG, DM, and EtOH abuse. He was transferred to the ICU after an aborted cardiac catheterization due to agitation. He has a new stent in the SVG-OM1 and is awaiting catheterization on January 24th for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA occlusion. He has been experiencing agitation, confusion, and chest pain, and has been refusing EKG and PO meds. He has a history of acute on chronic systolic CHF, and his cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Unstable angina and NSTEMI: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina, and his enzymes were suggestive of NSTEMI. He has a new stent in the SVG-OM1, and his cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation. He is awaiting catheterization on January 24th for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA occlusion.
2. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient has a history of CHF with an EF of 51%, and he has persistent fluid overload on admission. He is at risk for worsening CHF and respiratory distress.
3. Agitation and confusion: The patient has been experiencing agitation and confusion since his hospitalization, and his primary process appears to be agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium. He may have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal, and he is at risk for further agitation and confusion.
4. Benzodiazepine withdrawal: The patient has been taking Ativan PO PRN at home, and he may have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. He is at risk for further agitation and confusion.
5. EtOH abuse: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse, and he has been drinking a pint of whiskey a day at home. He is at risk for EtOH withdrawal, and he may have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
6. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient has a history of DM, and he is at risk for developing diabetic ketoacidosis due to his poor glycemic control.
7. Pneumonia: The patient has a history of respiratory failure, and he is at risk for developing pneumonia.
8. Sepsis: The patient has a history of cardiac catheterization, and he is at risk for developing sepsis due to his increased risk of infection.
9. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of AF, and he is at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias due to his cardiac disease and medications.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for developing various medical complications, including unstable angina and NSTEMI, acute on chronic systolic CHF, agitation and confusion, benzodiazepine withdrawal, EtOH abuse, diabetic ketoacidosis, pneumonia, sepsis, and cardiac arrhythmias. Close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

The patient has been experiencing agitation, confusion, and chest pain, which has been managed with IV Ativan and Morphine. He has also been experiencing respiratory distress and requires oxygen therapy. The patient's cardiac catheterization revealed occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, and he is awaiting further evaluation and treatment. The patient's medical history includes NSTEMI, acute on chronic systolic CHF, and EtOH abuse.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization revealed occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, which may lead to further cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, or cardiac failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory distress and oxygen requirement may lead to respiratory complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory failure.

Summary:

The patient, a 72-inch tall, 104.6 kg male, has been in the ICU for an unknown duration, with a chief complaint of agitation, confusion, and chest pain. Despite receiving Ativan and Morphine, the patient remains agitated and has refused PO medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5C, heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure of 100/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient has a sinus rhythm and is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula. The patient's laboratory results show elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr) levels, with a hematocrit (Hct) of 33.8%. The patient is receiving cardiac and diabetic diets, as well as insulin and sliding scale glucose control.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Delirium: The patient's agitation and confusion may be indicative of delirium, which can be a complication of critical illness, particularly in older adults.
2. Chest Pain: The patient's reported chest pain may be a sign of underlying cardiac or pulmonary pathology, which requires further evaluation.
3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure of 100/66 mmHg may be indicative of hypertension, which can increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level of 187 mg/dL may be indicative of hyperglycemia, which can increase the risk of complications, particularly in patients with diabetes.
5. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's elevated BUN and Cr levels may be indicative of AKI, which can be a complication of critical illness, particularly in patients with underlying kidney disease.
6. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient is receiving prophylactic heparin, which may be necessary to prevent DVT, particularly in patients with immobility or underlying cardiovascular disease.
7. Stress Ulcer: The patient is receiving ranitidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis, which may be necessary to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly in critically ill patients.
8. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to the use of mechanical ventilation and the presence of a multi-lumen catheter.

The patient is a 72-inch tall, 104.6 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of altered mental status, myocardial infarction (AMI), and acute coronary syndrome. Over the past 24 hours, the patient has been agitated, confused, and refusing to take oral medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5C, heart rate of 95 bpm, and blood pressure of 100/66 mmHg. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including heparin, furosemide, ranitidine, lorazepam, and morphine.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Delirium: Despite the patient's altered mental status being attributed to AMI, there is a risk of delirium developing due to the patient's agitation, confusion, and refusal of medications.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's AMI diagnosis increases the risk of cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
3. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory support with nasal cannula oxygen and potential need for mechanical ventilation increases the risk of respiratory complications, including pneumonia and respiratory failure.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis with ranitidine and potential need for enteral nutrition increases the risk of gastrointestinal complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and bowel obstruction.
5. Fluid and Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's fluid balance and electrolyte levels require close monitoring to prevent complications such as hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and acidosis.
6. Infection: The patient's indwelling catheters and invasive lines increase the risk of infection, including central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) and catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI).
7. Thrombosis: The patient's heparin therapy increases the risk of bleeding complications, including intracranial hemorrhage and gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Medication Errors: The patient's complex medication regimen and potential for medication errors increases the risk of adverse drug reactions and medication-related complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, transferred to CCU
   after aborted cardiac catheterization caused by agitation following an
   OSH ICU admission for respiratory failure & NSTEMI.
   .
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Currently, patient has a new
   stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. He is awaiting
   catheterization on [**1-24**] for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA
   occlusion. Currently, he is chest pain free, with negative CE
s, but
   refusing EKG.
   - ASA 325mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Plavix 75mg daily
   - Increase Metoprolol Tartrate to 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg TID when
   tolerating PO
   - Heparin gtt
   - No Integrillin given current Troponin
   - Morphine PRN: chest pain
   - Will continue to try and obtain EKG
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**]. Patient with persistent fluid overload
   on admission, but he was not pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac
   catheterization. On transfer, patient demonstrates mild respiratory
   distress and O2 requirement, limited clinical exam suggests fluid
   overload. Received IV Lasix on transfer with good UOP, but remains
   fluid overloaded this AM.
   - TTE today
   - Repeat Lasix 40mg IV x 1 this AM, goal -1L today
   - O2 by NC
   - Increase Metoprolol Tartrate 10mg IV q6H or 37.5mg TID when
   tolerating PO
   - Increase Lisinopril 5mg daily
   # Agitation/Mental status changes: Patient's cardiac catheterization
   aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to significant doses of
   Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital records, patient has
   been confused and agitated since his hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. He
   pulled out his Foley prior to transfer to the [**Hospital1 19**] and his wife
   reports that he was paranoid at [**Location (un) 755**], insisting that the FBI was out
   to get him. At home, however, his wife states that he is not confused,
   but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As patient has been

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and recent NSTEMI. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure and NSTEMI. The patient's cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation, and he was transferred to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Agitation and confusion, requiring frequent reorientation and sedation with Ativan
* Chest pain, which is currently managed with morphine and nitrates
* Respiratory distress, requiring oxygen therapy
* Fluid overload, requiring diuretic therapy with Lasix
* Tachycardia, which may be related to agitation or diuresis
* Mild edema in the lower extremities
* Short-term memory impairments and possible benzodiazepine withdrawal
* History of ethanol abuse and recent detoxification

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI and recent cardiac catheterization may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as acute coronary syndrome, cardiac arrhythmias, or cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory distress and fluid overload may increase the risk of respiratory failure, pneumonia, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's agitation, confusion, and possible benzodiazepine withdrawal may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, delirium, or stroke.
4. Infection: The patient's fluid overload and recent hospitalization may increase the risk of infection, such as urinary tract infection, pneumonia, or sepsis.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of ethanol abuse and possible benzodiazepine withdrawal may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Metabolic complications: The patient's diabetes and possible insulin resistance may increase the risk of metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, or hypoglycemia.
7. Renal complications: The patient's fluid overload and possible diuretic therapy may increase the risk of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his cardiac, respiratory, and neurological status. He should be continued on diuretic therapy to manage fluid overload, and his insulin regimen should be adjusted as needed to manage his blood glucose levels. The patient's agitation and confusion should be managed with frequent reorientation, sedation with Ativan, and possible psych consult. The patient's history of ethanol abuse and possible benzodiazepine withdrawal should be monitored closely, and he should be referred to a substance abuse program for further treatment.

Based on the patient's 24-hour events, it appears that the patient has been experiencing agitation, confusion, and chest pain, which has been managed with IV Ativan and Morphine. The patient has also been refusing PO medications and has been unable to tolerate EKGs due to agitation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, suggesting NSTEMI, and abnormal cardiac enzymes. The patient has a history of CABG and DM, and has been taking medications for these conditions.

The patient's physical examination reveals that he is well-nourished, overweight, and agitated, with right lower extremity edema. His respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen, and his vital signs are stable.

The patient's medical history is significant for NSTEMI, CABG, DM, and EtOH abuse. He has also been experiencing agitation, confusion, and short-term memory impairments, which may be related to benzodiazepine withdrawal.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI and history of CABG place him at risk for cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and myocardial infarction.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory distress and oxygen requirement may worsen if not managed properly.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's agitation, confusion, and short-term memory impairments may be related to benzodiazepine withdrawal or underlying neurological disorders.
4. Infectious complications: The patient's history of EtOH abuse and recent hospitalization may increase his risk for infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload and edema may worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory and cardiac complications.
6. Medication complications: The patient's complex medication regimen may increase his risk for medication interactions, side effects, and complications.
7. Psychological complications: The patient's agitation, confusion, and short-term memory impairments may worsen if not managed properly, leading to psychological complications such as depression, anxiety, and psychosis.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent these complications and ensure the patient's optimal care.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, and NSTEMI. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, NSTEMI, and possible PNA. The patient's condition has been complex and challenging to manage.

The patient's respiratory status has been unstable, with tachypnea, hypoxia, and hypercarbia. He was intubated due to his respiratory distress and requires mechanical ventilation. The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with NSTEMI, possible PNA, and a history of CABG.

The patient's mental status has been altered, with agitation, confusion, and possible dementia/delirium. He has been receiving Haldol for restraint and sedation. The patient's urine output has been poor, with a Foley catheter in place.

The patient's laboratory results show abnormalities, including elevated troponin, creatinine, and lactate levels. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a normal sinus rhythm with possible ST-segment depression.

The patient's imaging studies, including a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), show left ventricular cavity enlargement with moderate global hypokinesis, mild aortic valve stenosis, and moderate mitral regurgitation.

The patient's medications include anticoagulation therapy with heparin, antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, beta-blockers with metoprolol, and insulin therapy with NPH and sliding scale.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires mechanical ventilation. He is at risk for further respiratory failure and possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of NSTEMI, possible PNA, and CABG. He is at risk for further cardiac complications, including heart failure, arrhythmias, and possible cardiac arrest.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's mental status is altered, and he is at risk for further neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, and possible brain death.
4. Renal complications: The patient's urine output is poor, and he is at risk for further renal complications, including acute kidney injury and possible chronic kidney disease.
5. Infection: The patient has a Foley catheter in place, and he is at risk for urinary tract infections (UTIs). He also has a history of EtOH abuse, which increases his risk for infections.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and challenging to manage. He requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, neurological, and renal status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory distress: He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%.
* Cardiovascular: He has a new stent in the SVG-OM1 graft and is awaiting further evaluation and treatment for the LIMA-LAD graft occlusion.
* Neurological: He has a small lacunar infarct in the anterior limb of the right internal capsule, which was detected on CT head, and is being monitored by neurology.
* Infection: He has a left lower lobe pneumonia, which was detected on CT chest, and is being treated with Vancomycin and Cefepime.
* Metabolic: He has a complex metabolic disturbance, including hyperglycemia, and is being managed with insulin sliding scale and NPH.
* Psychiatric: He has a history of agitation and confusion, which is being managed with Haldol and Ativan.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen, requiring further interventions such as increased PEEP or the use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac condition may deteriorate, requiring further interventions such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
* Neurological complications: The patient's neurological condition may worsen, requiring further interventions such as thrombolysis or surgical decompression.
* Infection: The patient's infection may spread to other areas of the body, requiring further antibiotics and supportive care.
* Metabolic complications: The patient's metabolic disturbance may worsen, requiring further interventions such as insulin therapy or glucose monitoring.
* Psychiatric complications: The patient's psychiatric condition may worsen, requiring further interventions such as increased sedation or psychiatric consultation.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to prevent and manage potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and a recent aborted cardiac catheterization due to agitation. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation for respiratory distress.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Left lower lobe pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions, which are being treated with vancomycin and cefepime.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 1.3 mg/dL.
3. Hypotension requiring pressors.
4. Hyperglycemia with a glucose level of 176 mg/dL.
5. Mild interstitial pulmonary edema on chest CT.
6. Age-indeterminate infarct in the anterior limb of the right internal capsule on head CT, which is being further evaluated with MRI.
7. Agitation and mental status changes, which are being treated with Haldol and Ativan.
8. History of ethanol abuse and possible benzodiazepine withdrawal.
9. Recent stent placement in the SVG-OM1 graft.
10. Chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 51% on nuclear imaging.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's pneumonia and AKI.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to the patient's history of NSTEMI and CHF.
3. Respiratory failure or respiratory arrest due to the patient's pneumonia and AKI.
4. Neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures, due to the patient's age-indeterminate infarct and history of ethanol abuse.
5. Infection or abscess formation due to the patient's indwelling catheters and lines.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to the patient's history of ethanol abuse and possible gastrointestinal disease.
7. Psychiatric complications, such as depression or anxiety, due to the patient's history of ethanol abuse and recent agitation and mental status changes.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued mechanical ventilation for respiratory distress.
2. Antibiotic therapy for pneumonia and AKI.
3. Pressor therapy for hypotension.
4. Glycemic control with NPH and sliding scale insulin.
5. Monitoring of cardiac rhythm and function.
6. Further evaluation of the patient's age-indeterminate infarct with MRI.
7. Management of the patient's agitation and mental status changes with Haldol and Ativan.
8. Treatment of the patient's history of ethanol abuse and possible benzodiazepine withdrawal.
9. Continued monitoring of the patient's electrolyte levels and fluid status.
10. Further work-up and treatment of the patient's chronic systolic CHF.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting, diabetes, and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He was intubated due to worsening respiratory status and low-grade fever. CT chest revealed left lower lobe pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions. He was started on vancomycin and cefepime empirically, and urine and blood cultures are pending.

The patient has a complex medical history, including a small lacunar infarct in the anterior limb of the right internal capsule, which was discovered on CT head. He also has a history of agitation and mental status changes, which are being managed with Haldol and frequent reorientation. His primary process appears to be agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium, and he may have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal.

The patient has a new stent in the SVG-OM1 graft, which was partially expanded during cardiac catheterization. He was awaiting further evaluation and treatment of the LIMA-LAD graft occlusion. He has a history of acute on chronic systolic heart failure, and his ejection fraction is 30-35%. He is currently hypotensive and requires pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's left lower lobe pneumonia may progress and require additional antibiotics or other interventions.
2. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, requiring further interventions such as mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
3. Heart Failure: The patient's heart failure may worsen, requiring additional medications or interventions such as inotropes or vasopressors.
4. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and pleural effusions may lead to sepsis or other infections, which could worsen his condition.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's small lacunar infarct may lead to neurological deficits or further infarcts, which could worsen his condition.
6. Benzodiazepine Withdrawal: The patient's benzodiazepine withdrawal may lead to seizures, hallucinations, or other withdrawal symptoms.
7. Delirium: The patient's agitation and mental status changes may worsen, requiring additional interventions such as sedation or antipsychotics.
8. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and pleural effusions may lead to sepsis, which could worsen his condition.
10. Organ Failure: The patient's underlying medical conditions may lead to organ failure, such as kidney or liver failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-inch tall, 104.6 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status. A CT head scan revealed an age-indeterminate infarct in the anterior limb of the right internal capsule, which the radiologist recommends further evaluation with an MRI. A CT chest scan showed left lower lobe pneumonia, mild interstitial pulmonary edema, and large right and small left pleural effusions.

The patient has been receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefepime, for pneumonia. He has also been receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin for prophylaxis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4C, heart rate of 86 bpm, and blood pressure of 88/42 mmHg. His respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, and elevated white blood cell count, with a count of 247 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 5.2 mEq/L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infarct progression: The patient's age-indeterminate infarct in the anterior limb of the right internal capsule may progress, leading to further neurological deficits.
2. Pneumonia progression: The patient's left lower lobe pneumonia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and the need for more aggressive respiratory support.
3. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and pulmonary edema may lead to sepsis, which could result in multi-organ failure.
4. Vascular events: The patient's anticoagulation therapy may increase the risk of bleeding, while the presence of a large right pleural effusion may increase the risk of respiratory compromise.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be adequate, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient's anemia and elevated white blood cell count may increase the risk of renal dysfunction.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and pulmonary edema may lead to respiratory failure, which could result in the need for more aggressive respiratory support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented

   stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. Patient returned to
   cath on [**1-25**] and had a PROMUS to the LIMA. His Right heart cath had a
   PCWP of 15 . On [**1-25**], patient has MAPs of roughly 50, on levophed
   implying shock.

   empirically. Urine culture from [**2182-1-23**] negative. ABG

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting, diabetes, and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). His cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation, and he was found to have occlusion of the saphenous vein graft-omental 1 (SVG-OM1) and left internal mammary artery (LIMA) grafts. He was intubated and required pressors to maintain blood pressure.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory distress with complex metabolic disturbance, including left lower lobe pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions
* Acute on chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 30-35%
* Agitation and mental status changes, including confusion, agitation, and short-term memory impairments
* History of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and cerebrovascular accidents (CVAs)
* Diabetes, ethanol abuse, and hypertension
* Abnormal laboratory results, including elevated troponin levels, low platelet count, and abnormal liver function tests

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization was aborted due to agitation, and he has a history of cardiac disease. He may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient has respiratory distress and is intubated. He may be at risk for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of TIAs and CVAs, and he is currently experiencing agitation and mental status changes. He may be at risk for further neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, and brain edema.
4. Metabolic complications: The patient has diabetes and ethanol abuse, which may increase his risk for metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Infection complications: The patient has a history of pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions, which may increase his risk for infection complications, such as sepsis and septic shock.
6. Bleeding complications: The patient has a history of bleeding complications, including a meatal bleed, which may increase his risk for further bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition and multiple comorbidities make him at high risk for a variety of medical complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, and transferred to the ICU after an aborted cardiac catheterization due to agitation. He was intubated on January 23rd for worsening respiratory status and low-grade fever. CT chest demonstrated left lower lobe pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions. He was started on Vancomycin and Cefepime empirically.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T max 37.2C, T current 37.1C, HR 84 bpm, BP 97/40 mmHg, RR 15 insp/min, SpO2 97%
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, CPAP/PSV mode, Vt 423 mL, PS 10 cmH2O, RR 16, PEEP 5 cmH2O, FiO2 40%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Arterial line, central venous pressure (CVP) not measured
* Fluid balance: Total in 3728 mL, total out 686 mL, balance 3042 mL
* Labs: WBC 6.0, Hct 28.9, Plt 208 K/uL, Cr 1.0 mg/dL, TCO2 30 mmHg, Glucose 155 mg/dL
* CXR: Small pleural effusions on both sides, left lower lobe atelectasis worsened
* EKG: Normal sinus rhythm
* Cardiovascular: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of NSTEMI
* Respiratory distress: Patient intubated on January 23rd for worsening respiratory status and low-grade fever
* Acute on chronic systolic CHF: Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization
* Agitation/Mental status changes/CVA's/Hx of TIA: Patient's cardiac catheterization aborted due to agitation, patient has been confused and agitated since hospitalization
* DM: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, currently on NPH and insulin sliding scale
* EtOH abuse: Patient drinks a pint of whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]
* HLD: Patient on Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* HTN: Patient currently hypotensive, requiring pressors
* GERD: Patient on Lansoprazole 30mg daily
* Anxiety/Depression: Patient's mental status is a distant diagnosis, currently being observed

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia and sepsis due to the patient's respiratory distress and low-grade fever
* Acute kidney injury due to hypotension and fluid overload
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's history of NSTEMI and CHF
* Sepsis and organ dysfunction due to the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular instability
* Benzodiazepine withdrawal due to the patient's history of EtOH abuse and use of Ativan
* Delirium and dementia due to the patient's age and history of EtOH abuse
* Stroke and TIA due to the patient's history of EtOH abuse and use of Ativan
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's history of GERD and use of anticoagulants

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue IV Vancomycin and Cefepime empirically
* Wean pressors as tolerated
* Attempt extubation today
* Continue NPH and insulin sliding scale
* Start Metoprolol Tartrate and Lisinopril when BP can tolerate
* Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* Continue Lansoprazole 30mg daily
* Continue IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN when extubated
* SW consult
* Continue to observe for signs of delirium and dementia
* Continue to monitor for signs of sepsis and organ dysfunction

s tolerate

   bilateral pleural effusions. Started on Vancomycin & Cefepime
   empirically. Urine culture from [**2182-1-23**] negative. ABG
s improving. RSBI
   56 on the morning of [**1-27**].
   - continue IV Vancomycin, day 5,  Cefepime, day 5
   - Frequent ABG
   - wean off sedation
   - attempt extubation today

   .
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on
   [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on
   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was being weaned.
   - continue to wean pressor as tolerated
   - give 1u pRBC today
   - keep even fluid balance today
   - will start Metoprolol Tartrate and Lisinopril when BP can tolerate
   .

   catheterization aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to

   territories, suggesting a proximal source (heart or the aorta). This
   CVA may be complicating already complex delirium and dementia picture.

   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes as possible
   .

   - On telemetry
   - will start BB when BP can tolerate
   .

   .

   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN when extubated
   - SW consult
   .

   .

   - will restart Lisinopril and Metoprolol Tartrate when bp

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a complex medical history, including CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, and a recent NSTEMI. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and was intubated on January 23rd. His current vital signs are:

* T: 37.2C (98.9F)
* HR: 84 bpm (84-121 bpm)
* BP: 97/40 mmHg (60/38-115/64 mmHg)
* RR: 15 inspirations per minute (13-24 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 6.0 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 28.9%
* Plt: 208 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 1.0 mg/dL
* TCO2: 30 mmHg
* Glucose: 155 mg/dL

The patient's chest X-ray shows small pleural effusions and left lower lobe atelectasis, which has worsened since admission.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization were concerning for unstable angina, and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation.
* Respiratory Distress with Complex Metabolic Disturbance: The patient was intubated due to worsening respiratory status and low-grade fever. He has bilateral pleural effusions and left lower lobe pneumonia.
* Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has persistent fluid overload and was not pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization.
* Agitation/Mental status changes/CVA's/Hx of TIA: The patient has been confused and agitated since hospitalization, and has a small lacunar infarct on CT head.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require further mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI/CAD may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
* Renal insufficiency: The patient's Cr level is 1.0 mg/dL, which may indicate renal insufficiency.
* Infection: The patient has bilateral pleural effusions and left lower lobe pneumonia, which may lead to further infection.
* Neurological complications: The patient has a small lacunar infarct on CT head, which may lead to further neurological complications, such as stroke or TIA.
* Fluid overload: The patient has persistent fluid overload, which may lead to further complications, such as pulmonary edema or cardiac failure.
* Benzodiazepine withdrawal: The patient takes Ativan at home and may have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
* Delirium: The patient has been confused and agitated since hospitalization, which may be due to delirium or dementia.
* Anxiety/depression: The patient may have underlying anxiety or depression, which may need to be addressed.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue IV Vancomycin and Cefepime empirically.
* Wean off sedation.
* Attempt extubation today.
* Haldol prn after extubation.
* Continue IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN when extubated.
* SW consult.
* Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
* Continue Lisinopril and Metoprolol Tartrate when BP can tolerate.
* Continue NPH and insulin sliding scale from OSH.
* Continue Lansoprazole 30mg daily.
* Continue to observe for anxiety/depression.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol (EtOH) abuse, who was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) after an aborted cardiac catheterization due to agitation following an outpatient surgery (OSH) admission for respiratory failure and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). The patient has been intubated and ventilated, and has been treated with antibiotics, anticoagulation, and vasopressors.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a heart rate of 109 beats per minute, blood pressure of 123/59 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 591 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.

The patient has a history of cardiac catheterization, which showed occlusion of the saphenous vein graft (SVG) and left internal mammary artery (LIMA) grafts. The patient's right heart catheterization showed a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) of 15 mmHg.

The patient has also had a small lacunar infarct of indeterminate age on a computed tomography (CT) head scan, which may be complicating his delirium and dementia.

The patient's medications include:

* Aspirin 325mg daily
* Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* Plavix 75mg daily
* Metoprolol tartrate 25mg PO BID
* Lansoprazole 30mg daily
* Gabapentin (held)
* NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
* Insulin sliding scale
* Haldol (as needed)
* Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of respiratory failure due to his underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and the use of mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac catheterization and has been treated with vasopressors, which may increase the risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
3. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of small lacunar infarcts and may be at risk for further neurological complications such as stroke or seizures.
4. Infection: The patient has been treated with antibiotics and has a risk of infection due to his underlying medical conditions and the use of invasive devices such as central lines and urinary catheters.
5. Delirium and dementia: The patient has a history of delirium and dementia, which may be exacerbated by his underlying medical conditions and the use of sedatives and analgesics.
6. Fluid overload: The patient has a history of fluid overload, which may be exacerbated by his underlying medical conditions and the use of diuretics.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and may be at risk for further gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his vasopressor settings as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his sedative and analgesic medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and adjust his antibiotic medications as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust his diuretic medications as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his medications as needed.
7. Consider consulting with a neurologist and a psychiatrist to further evaluate the patient's delirium and dementia.

   after aborted cardiac catheterization caused by agitation following an
   OSH ICU admission for respiratory failure & NSTEMI.
   .

   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are

   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Patient returned to cath on [**1-25**]
   and had a PROMUS to the LIMA. His Right heart cath had a PCWP of 15 .
   Since intubation, patient has been on varying rates of levophed
   infusion. Levophed was being weaned off [**1-26**]. Has since been extubated
   - ASA 325mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Plavix 75mg daily
   - consider starting low dose beta blocker today
 will discuss with
   attending
   .

   intubated on [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and
   low-grade fever. CT chest demonstrated left lower lobe pneumonia and
   bilateral pleural effusions. Started on Vancomycin & Cefepime
   empirically. Urine culture from [**2182-1-23**] negative. ABG
s improving. RSBI
   56 on the morning of [**1-27**].  Pt extubated on [**2182-1-27**]. Put on BiPAP.
   Tolerating well with good oxygenation. Some CO2 retention however, pH
   relatively normal. [**Month (only) 51**] have been retaining chronically but appears
   compensated. Will continue to follow with ABGs.
   - continue IV Vancomycin, day 6,  Cefepime, day 6

   .

   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on
   [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on
   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was being weaned.
   - off levophed
   - consider transfusion
 no evidence of hypoperfusion
   - keep even fluid balance today
   - will start Metoprolol Tartrate and Lisinopril when BP can tolerate
   .

   catheterization aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to
   significant doses of Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital
   records, patient has been confused and agitated since his
   hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. At home, however, his wife states that he
   is not confused, but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As
   patient has been attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is
   not fully oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary
   process appears to be agitation with some minor component of
   dementia/delirium. Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may
   have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Normal metabolic
   work-up as an inpatient. CT head on [**1-24**] demonstrated a small lacunar
   infarct of indeterminate age, so neurology was consulted. Neuro finds
   Small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular
   territories, suggesting a proximal source (heart or the aorta). This
   CVA may be complicating already complex delirium and dementia picture.

   - F/U Psych recs

   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes as possible
   .
   #. Rhythm: Patient in normal sinus rhythm/sinus tachycardia. Prior
   report of AF was likely telemetry static.
   - On telemetry
   - will start BB when BP can tolerate
   .
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.  Home
   Gabapentin held.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   .
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.

   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a complex medical history, including CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, and a recent NSTEMI. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, agitation, and hemodynamic instability. The patient has undergone several interventions, including cardiac catheterization, intubation, and extubation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on BiPAP and tolerating it well, with good oxygenation. However, he has some CO2 retention, and his pH is relatively normal.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of CAD, and his cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He has been on varying rates of levophed infusion and has been weaned off it. He is currently on ASA, Atorvastatin, and Plavix.
* Renal: The patient has been retaining chronically, but appears to be compensated. His creatinine is 1.0, and his BUN is 30 mg/dL.
* Neurological: The patient has a small lacunar infarct of indeterminate age on CT head, and neurology has been consulted. He is agitated and disoriented, and has a history of TIA.
* Metabolic: The patient has DM and is on NPH and insulin sliding scale. He also has a history of EtOH abuse and has been maintained on CIWA scale during previous hospitalizations.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory: Pneumonia, respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Cardiovascular: Cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and acute coronary syndrome.
* Renal: Acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD).
* Neurological: Stroke, seizures, and delirium.
* Metabolic: Hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Infection: Sepsis and bacteremia.

The patient's current medications include:

* Cardiovascular: ASA, Atorvastatin, Plavix
* Respiratory: BiPAP
* Renal: Lasix
* Neurological: Haldol, Ativan
* Metabolic: NPH, insulin sliding scale
* EtOH withdrawal: IV Ativan
* Prophylaxis: SQ UF Heparin, lansoprazole

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue IV Vancomycin and Cefepime
* Frequent ABG
* Wean off O2 as tolerated
* Haldol PRN
* Consider starting low-dose beta blocker
* Continue IV Lasix
* Consider transfusion
* Start Metoprolol Tartrate and Lisinopril when BP can tolerate
* Continue NPH and insulin sliding scale
* IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN when extubated per CIWA scale
* SW consult
* Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* Lansoprazole 30mg daily

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and NSTEMI following an aborted cardiac catheterization due to agitation. He was intubated for respiratory distress and had a successful stenting procedure. He was extubated and placed on BiPAP, which was weaned this morning. The patient has a history of CABG, DM, and EtOH abuse. He is currently receiving antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and other medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C, heart rate of 109 bpm, and blood pressure of 123/59 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 23 breaths per minute, and his SpO2 is 98%. He has a mild degree of right lower extremity edema and left lower extremity edema.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 5.5
* Hct: 25.5
* Plt: 208
* Cr: 1.0
* TCO2: 28
* Glucose: 172
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 15.3 / 35.6 / 1.3, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T: 38 / 3 / 0.11, Lactic Acid: 0.7 mmol/L, Ca++: 8.1 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.7 mg/dL, PO4: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: Left lower lobe atelectasis has worsened and small pleural effusions have increased. Size of the at least mildly enlarged heart is difficult to assess because of patient rotation. There is no pneumothorax. Pleural effusion if any is small, on both sides of the chest.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk for further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure due to atelectasis.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of CABG and NSTEMI, and is at risk for further cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
* Infection: The patient has a history of UTI and is at risk for further infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
* Metabolic complications: The patient has diabetes and is at risk for further metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
* Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status and is at risk for further neurological complications, such as delirium or seizures.

   INDICATION: 82-year-old man with NSTEMI, respiratory failure and status
   post
   placement of NG tube. Evaluate for position of NG tube.
   COMPARISON: Multiple priors, most recent portable AP chest radiograph
   [**2182-1-28**].
   TECHNIQUE: Portable AP chest radiograph.
   FINDINGS: Comparison is made to portable AP chest radiograph obtained
   earlier
   today. Gastric tube is noted to extend beyond the level of the
   diaphragm with
   tip coiled within the stomach. Otherwise, no interval change noted from
   most
   recent portable AP chest radiograph obtained earlier today.
   ECG: 12:30am - Normal sinus rhythm, no ST changes.  No evidence of RV
   strain.
   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, transferred to CCU
   after aborted cardiac catheterization caused by agitation following an
   OSH ICU admission for respiratory failure & NSTEMI.
   .
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Patient returned to cath on [**1-25**]
   and had a PROMUS to the LIMA. His Right heart cath had a PCWP of 15 .
   Since intubation, patient has been on varying rates of levophed
   infusion. Levophed was being weaned off [**1-26**]. Has since been extubated.
   Pressures have been stable enough to start beta blocker.
   - ASA 325mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Plavix 75mg daily
   - start metoprolol 25mg PO BID
   .
   # Respiratory Distress with Complex Metabolic Disturbance: Patient
   intubated on [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and
   low-grade fever. CT chest demonstrated left lower lobe pneumonia and
   bilateral pleural effusions. Started on Vancomycin & Cefepime
   empirically. Urine culture from [**2182-1-23**] negative. ABG
s improving. RSBI
   56 on the morning of [**1-27**].  Pt extubated on [**2182-1-27**]. Put on BiPAP.
   Tolerating well with good oxygenation. Some CO2 retention however, pH
   relatively normal. [**Month (only) 51**] have been retaining chronically but appears
   compensated. Will continue to follow with ABGs. Afebrile, some
   coughing, no production. Lungs with bibasilar crackles.
   - continue IV Vancomycin, day 6,  Cefepime, day 6 (plan for 8 day
   course)
   - Frequent ABG
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   .
   #. Sinus Tachycardia: Unclear etiology. Had fluid challenge and pRBCs
   yesterday without improvement. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to volume status. CVP
   checked and is low at 4-7. No evidence of PE, on prophylaxis. No
   evidence of active ischemia. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to beta blocker
   withdrawal vs agitation/delirium.
   - attempt to minimize delirium as below
   - start metoprolol tartrate 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - will need NG tube for medications
   - cont tele
   .
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on
   [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on
   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was weaned.  Currently stable pressures.
   - consider transfusion if evidence of hypoperfusion
 none at this time
   - keep even fluid balance today
   - start metoprolol tartrate today
   .
   # Agitation/Mental status changes/CVA's/Hx of TIA: Patient's cardiac
   catheterization aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to
   significant doses of Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital
   records, patient has been confused and agitated since his
   hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. At home, however, his wife states that he
   is not confused, but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As
   patient has been attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is
   not fully oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary
   process appears to be agitation with some minor component of
   dementia/delirium. Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may
   have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Normal metabolic
   work-up as an inpatient. CT head on [**1-24**] demonstrated a small lacunar
   infarct of indeterminate age, so neurology was consulted. Neuro finds
   Small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular
   territories, suggesting a proximal source (heart or the aorta). This
   CVA may be complicating already complex delirium and dementia picture.
   - carotids

   - 4 bed rail restraint, 2 ext restraints
 pulling at lines
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes as possible
   - NGT today for medications
   .
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.  Home
   Gabapentin held.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   .
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Now is outside

   - SW consult  when mental status improves
   .
