   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, transferred to CCU
   after aborted cardiac catheterization caused by agitation following an
   OSH ICU admission for respiratory failure & NSTEMI.
   .
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Patient returned to cath on [**1-25**]
   and had a PROMUS to the LIMA. His Right heart cath had a PCWP of 15 .
   Since intubation, patient has been on varying rates of levophed
   infusion. Levophed was being weaned off [**1-26**]. Has since been extubated.
   Pressures have been stable enough to start beta blocker.
   - ASA 325mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Plavix 75mg daily
   - start metoprolol 25mg PO BID
   .
   # Respiratory Distress with Complex Metabolic Disturbance: Patient
   intubated on [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and
   low-grade fever. CT chest demonstrated left lower lobe pneumonia and
   bilateral pleural effusions. Started on Vancomycin & Cefepime
   empirically. Urine culture from [**2182-1-23**] negative. ABG
s improving. RSBI
   56 on the morning of [**1-27**].  Pt extubated on [**2182-1-27**]. Put on BiPAP.
   Tolerating well with good oxygenation. Some CO2 retention however, pH
   relatively normal. [**Month (only) 51**] have been retaining chronically but appears
   compensated. Will continue to follow with ABGs. Afebrile, some
   coughing, no production. Lungs with bibasilar crackles.
   - continue IV Vancomycin, day 6,  Cefepime, day 6 (plan for 8 day
   course)
   - Frequent ABG
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   .
   #. Sinus Tachycardia: Unclear etiology. Had fluid challenge and pRBCs
   yesterday without improvement. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to volume status. CVP
   checked and is low at 4-7. No evidence of PE, on prophylaxis. No
   evidence of active ischemia. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to beta blocker
   withdrawal vs agitation/delirium.
   - attempt to minimize delirium as below
   - start metoprolol tartrate 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - will need NG tube for medications
   - cont tele
   .
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on
   [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on
   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was weaned.  Currently stable pressures.
   - consider transfusion if evidence of hypoperfusion
 none at this time
   - keep even fluid balance today
   - start metoprolol tartrate today
   .
   # Agitation/Mental status changes/CVA's/Hx of TIA: Patient's cardiac
   catheterization aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to
   significant doses of Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital
   records, patient has been confused and agitated since his
   hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. At home, however, his wife states that he
   is not confused, but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As
   patient has been attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is
   not fully oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary
   process appears to be agitation with some minor component of
   dementia/delirium. Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may
   have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Normal metabolic
   work-up as an inpatient. CT head on [**1-24**] demonstrated a small lacunar
   infarct of indeterminate age, so neurology was consulted. Neuro finds
   Small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular
   territories, suggesting a proximal source (heart or the aorta). This
   CVA may be complicating already complex delirium and dementia picture.
   - carotids
   - f/u hemoglobin a1c
   - F/U Neurology recs
   - F/U Psych recs
   - 4 bed rail restraint, 2 ext restraints
 pulling at lines
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes as possible
   - NGT today for medications
   .
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.  Home
   Gabapentin held.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   .
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Now is outside
   window for EtOH withdrawal. Will need monitoring for benzo withdrawal.
   - SW consult  when mental status improves
   .
   #. HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old man with a complex medical history, including NSTEMI, respiratory failure, and status post NG tube placement. The patient's condition is stable, with no significant changes in his vital signs or laboratory results.

The patient is receiving various medications, including metoprolol, lasix, and heparin, and is being monitored for potential complications such as sinus tachycardia, acute on chronic systolic CHF, and agitation/delirium.

The patient's medical history is significant for CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, and a history of TIA. He is also taking multiple medications, including ASA, atorvastatin, plavix, and metoprolol.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* WBC: 6.0
* Hct: 26.6
* Plt: 248
* Cr: 1.0
* TCO2: 29
* Glucose: 146
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 15.3 / 35.6 / 1.3, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T: 38 / 3 / 0.11, Lactic Acid: 0.7 mmol/L, Ca++: 8.1 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.8 mg/dL, PO4: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies include a CXR, which shows a small pleural effusion and bibasilar crackles, and a TTE, which shows an EF of 30-35% with global hypokinesis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue IV Vancomycin and Cefepime for 8 days
* Wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
* Monitor for potential complications such as sinus tachycardia, acute on chronic systolic CHF, and agitation/delirium
* Continue metoprolol tartrate 25mg PO BID
* Start Lasix 40mg IV daily
* Monitor for signs of hypoperfusion and consider transfusion if necessary
* Continue to monitor for signs of EtOH withdrawal and benzodiazepine withdrawal
* Continue to monitor for signs of delirium and agitation, and adjust medication as necessary

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sinus tachycardia
* Acute on chronic systolic CHF
* Agitation/delirium
* EtOH withdrawal
* Benzodiazepine withdrawal
* Hypoperfusion
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his plan of care as necessary to prevent or manage these potential complications.

* White blood cell count: 6.0 - 6.6 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 248 - 254 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0 - 0.9 mg/dL
* Blood glucose: 146 - 208 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show a normal sinus rhythm on ECG, with no evidence of RV strain. A CXR reveals that the NG tube is in place, extending beyond the level of the diaphragm with the tip coiled within the stomach.

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus, type II, urinary tract infection, respiratory failure, altered mental status, and acute myocardial infarction.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis or septic shock due to the presence of bloody sputum and urinary tract infection
* Respiratory failure or worsening respiratory status due to the patient's underlying condition and respiratory support
* Bleeding or hemorrhage due to the patient's platelet count and potential coagulopathy
* Metabolic acidosis or alkalosis due to the patient's blood glucose levels and potential electrolyte imbalances
* Cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure, due to the patient's underlying cardiovascular disease and medication regimen

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies closely to detect any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent worsening of the patient's condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   82M with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, presented to OSH with NSTEMI
   c/b respiratory failure requiring intubation, pna on abx, agitation and
   sinus tachycardia, now s/p PROMUS to LIMA.
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient presented to an outside hospital with angina
   and troponin elevation. No EKG from OSH. Likely NSTEMI given EKG at
   [**Hospital1 19**]. Serum troponin at admission of 0.04. The patient underwent
   cardiac catheterization which demonstrated occlusion of SVG-OM1 and
   LIMA-LAD grafts. The patient was very agitated during the procedure and
   the procedure was aborted. The patient returned to that cath lab and
   had a PROMUS placed in his LIMA. The patient is currently chest pain
   free and has been off NTG drip.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily
   - Clopidogrel 75mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Uptitrate metoprolol tartrate (currently at 37.5 [**Hospital1 7**]) to 50mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Consider adding low dose ACE inhibitor if pressures tolerate
   #. Respiratory failure: Unclear etiology. The patient was intubated on
   [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and low grade fever.
   The patient had a CT of the chest which demonstrated LLL pneumonia with
   bilateral pleural effusions. He was started on vancomycin and cefepime
   with a plan for an 8 day course. The patient was extubated on [**2182-1-27**].
   Put on BiPAP and tolerated with well. Was weaned to 50% FM and is
   currently oxygenating well. Patient is hypercarbic but with stable pH
   which means it may be chronic. Currently ABG appear stable but patient
   requiring large amounts of supplemental O2. Will continue to evaluated.
   CVP measured yesterday which was ~7 (although in context of single
   measurement is relatively meaningless).
   - continue IV vancomycin day 7, cefepime day 7 (plan for 8 day course)
   - continue frequent ABGs
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   - CXR - ?new consolidation, fluid status
   #. Sinus tachycardia: Unclear etiology. The patient had fluid challenge
   and pRBCs without clear any change in heart rate or blood pressure.
   Differential includes hypotension, PE, beta blocker withdrawal,
   hypoxia, fever, anxiety/agitation, hyperthyroidism, ischemia/MI, heart
   failure, chronic pulmonary disease. The patinet has a relatively low
   CVP but also did not respond to fluid challenges. Patient was
   anticoagulated and thus shouldn't have PE. ABG show patient isn't
   hypoxemic. No current fever. No history of hyperthyroidism or ongoing
   ischemia or MI. No history of pulmonary disease. Front runners include
   beta blocker withdrawal, anxiety/agitation and heart failure. Recent
   echo with maintained systolic function. Restarting beta blocker today.
   Will do best to control delirium and agitation with normal precautions.
   - minimize delirium
   - uptitrate metoprolol
   - continue tele
   - consider fluid challenge if continues
   - consider eval for PE
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on
   [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on
   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was weaned.  Currently stable pressures.
   - consider transfusion or IVF bolus if evidence of hypoperfusion
 none
   at this time
   - keep even fluid balance today
   - start metoprolol tartrate today
   # Agitation/Mental status changes/CVA's/Hx of TIA: Patient's cardiac
   catheterization aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to
   significant doses of Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital
   records, patient has been confused and agitated since his
   hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. At home, however, his wife states that he
   is not confused, but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As
   patient has been attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is
   not fully oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary
   process appears to be agitation with some minor component of
   dementia/delirium. Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may
   have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Normal metabolic
   work-up as an inpatient. CT head on [**1-24**] demonstrated a small lacunar
   infarct of indeterminate age, so neurology was consulted. Neuro finds
   Small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular
   territories, suggesting a proximal source (heart or the aorta). This
   CVA may be complicating already complex delirium and dementia picture.
   - consider carotid u/s per neuro recs
   - f/u hemoglobin A1C
   - F/U Neurology recs
   - F/U Psych recs
   - 4 bed rail restraint, 2 ext restraints

   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and EtOH abuse, who presented to the hospital with NSTEMI and was subsequently intubated due to respiratory failure. The patient has undergone cardiac catheterization and stent placement in the LIMA.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is currently on BiPAP and is oxygenating well, but still requires large amounts of supplemental O2.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a history of NSTEMI and has undergone cardiac catheterization and stent placement. His EF is 30-35% with global hypokinesis.
* Neurological status: The patient has a small lacunar infarct of indeterminate age and has been diagnosed with agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium.
* Medications: The patient is currently receiving metoprolol tartrate, vancomycin, cefepime, lasix, and other medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he requires large amounts of supplemental O2. There is a risk of further respiratory decline or complications such as pneumonia.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of NSTEMI and has undergone cardiac catheterization and stent placement. There is a risk of further cardiovascular complications such as MI, heart failure, or arrhythmias.
* Neurological complications: The patient has a small lacunar infarct of indeterminate age and has been diagnosed with agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium. There is a risk of further neurological decline or complications such as seizures or stroke.
* Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is currently receiving antibiotics. There is a risk of further infection or complications such as sepsis.
* Bleeding: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy and has a history of bleeding complications. There is a risk of further bleeding complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. It is essential to monitor his condition closely and adjust his medications and treatment plan accordingly to prevent further complications and improve his outcome.

   82M with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, presented to OSH with NSTEMI
   c/b respiratory failure requiring intubation, pna on abx, agitation and
   sinus tachycardia, now s/p PROMUS to LIMA.
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient presented to an outside hospital with angina
   and troponin elevation. No EKG from OSH. Likely NSTEMI given EKG at
   [**Hospital1 19**]. Serum troponin at admission of 0.04. The patient underwent
   cardiac catheterization which demonstrated occlusion of SVG-OM1 and
   LIMA-LAD grafts. The patient was very agitated during the procedure and
   the procedure was aborted. The patient returned to that cath lab and
   had a PROMUS placed in his LIMA. The patient is currently chest pain
   free and has been off NTG drip.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily
   - Clopidogrel 75mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Uptitrate metoprolol tartrate (currently at 37.5 [**Hospital1 7**]) to 50mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Consider adding low dose ACE inhibitor if pressures tolerate
   #. Respiratory failure: Unclear etiology. The patient was intubated on
   [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and low grade fever.
   The patient had a CT of the chest which demonstrated LLL pneumonia with
   bilateral pleural effusions. He was started on vancomycin and cefepime
   with a plan for an 8 day course. The patient was extubated on [**2182-1-27**].
   Put on BiPAP and tolerated with well. Was weaned to 50% FM and is
   currently oxygenating well. Patient is hypercarbic but with stable pH
   which means it may be chronic. Currently ABG appear stable but patient
   requiring large amounts of supplemental O2. Will continue to evaluated.
   CVP measured yesterday which was ~7 (although in context of single
   measurement is relatively meaningless).
   - continue IV vancomycin day 7, cefepime day 7 (plan for 8 day course)
   - continue frequent ABGs
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   - CXR - ?new consolidation, fluid status
   #. Sinus tachycardia: Unclear etiology. The patient had fluid challenge
   and pRBCs without clear any change in heart rate or blood pressure.
   Differential includes hypotension, PE, beta blocker withdrawal,
   hypoxia, fever, anxiety/agitation, hyperthyroidism, ischemia/MI, heart
   failure, chronic pulmonary disease. The patinet has a relatively low
   CVP but also did not respond to fluid challenges. Patient was
   anticoagulated and thus shouldn't have PE. ABG show patient isn't
   hypoxemic. No current fever. No history of hyperthyroidism or ongoing
   ischemia or MI. No history of pulmonary disease. Front runners include
   beta blocker withdrawal, anxiety/agitation and heart failure. Recent
   echo with maintained systolic function. Restarting beta blocker today.
   Will do best to control delirium and agitation with normal precautions.
   - minimize delirium
   - uptitrate metoprolol
   - continue tele
   - consider fluid challenge if continues
   - consider eval for PE
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on

   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was weaned.  Currently stable pressures.
   - consider transfusion or IVF bolus if evidence of hypoperfusion
 none
   at this time
   - keep even fluid balance today
   - start metoprolol tartrate today

   work-up as an inpatient. CT head on [**1-24**] demonstrated a small lacunar

   Small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the hospital with non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and was found to have occlusion of his left anterior descending (LAD) graft. He underwent cardiac catheterization and was placed on a stent in his left internal mammary artery (LIMA). He also has a history of respiratory failure, sinus tachycardia, and acute on chronic systolic heart failure.

Current status:

The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 97%. He has a temperature of 36.8C and a heart rate of 97 beats per minute. His blood pressure is 140/66 mmHg, and his central venous pressure (CVP) is 5 mmHg. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.0, a hemoglobin level of 9.9 g/dL, and a platelet count of 248. His troponin level is 0.11 ng/mL, and his creatinine level is 1.0 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac status is complex, and he may be at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he may be at risk for developing acute kidney injury.
5. Delirium: The patient's mental status is altered, and he may be at risk for developing delirium.
6. Benzodiazepine withdrawal: The patient has a history of benzodiazepine use and may be at risk for withdrawal symptoms.
7. EtOH withdrawal: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and may be at risk for withdrawal symptoms.
8. Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk for developing other infections.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide respiratory support as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and provide cardiac support as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and provide renal support as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and provide mental health support as needed.
5. Consider starting the patient on a beta blocker to control his heart rate.
6. Consider starting the patient on an anticoagulant to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
7. Continue to provide nutritional support to the patient.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid balance and provide fluid support as needed.
9. Consider starting the patient on a stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent stress ulcers.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and provide glucose control as needed.

   82M with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, presented to OSH with NSTEMI

   #. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient presented to an outside hospital with angina

   with a plan for an 8 day course. The patient was extubated on [**2182-1-27**].

   currently oxygenating well. Patient is hypercarbic but with stable pH
   which means it may be chronic. Currently ABG appear stable but patient
   requiring large amounts of supplemental O2. Will continue to evaluated.

   measurement is relatively meaningless).

   failure, chronic pulmonary disease. The patinet has a relatively low

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse, who presented to the hospital with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and respiratory failure. He underwent cardiac catheterization and placement of a PROMUS stent in his left internal mammary artery (LIMA). The patient has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of his respiratory failure, sinus tachycardia, and acute on chronic systolic heart failure.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including metoprolol, vancomycin, cefepime, and furosemide, and has had frequent arterial blood gas (ABG) measurements to monitor his respiratory status. His oxygenation has been stable, but he requires large amounts of supplemental oxygen.

The patient has also been experiencing agitation and delirium, which has been managed with reorientation and sedation. He has a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA) and has been diagnosed with small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular territories.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he requires large amounts of supplemental oxygen. Pneumonia is still a concern, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's respiratory failure and pneumonia increase his risk of developing sepsis. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's acute on chronic systolic heart failure increases his risk of developing cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias. Close monitoring of his cardiac status is necessary to detect any changes.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of CVA and small bihemispheric subacute infarcts increase his risk of developing neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures. Close monitoring of his neurological status is necessary to detect any changes.
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium and agitation increase his risk of developing complications, such as falls or injuries. Close monitoring of his mental status and aggressive management of his delirium are necessary to prevent these complications.
6. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and history of CVA increase his risk of developing infections. Close monitoring of his laboratory results and imaging studies is necessary to detect any signs of infection.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's acute on chronic systolic heart failure increases his risk of developing fluid overload. Close monitoring of his fluid status and aggressive management of his fluid overload are necessary to prevent complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his oxygen therapy as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust his medications as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust his medications as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's delirium and agitation aggressively, using reorientation and sedation as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and imaging studies closely for signs of infection or sepsis.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status closely and adjust his fluid management as necessary to prevent fluid overload.
7. Consider referring the patient to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of his CVA and small bihemispheric subacute infarcts.

   82M with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, presented to OSH with NSTEMI
   c/b respiratory failure requiring intubation, pna on abx, agitation and
   sinus tachycardia, now s/p PROMUS to LIMA.
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient presented to an outside hospital with angina
   and troponin elevation. No EKG from OSH. Likely NSTEMI given EKG at
   [**Hospital1 19**]. Serum troponin at admission of 0.04. The patient underwent
   cardiac catheterization which demonstrated occlusion of SVG-OM1 and
   LIMA-LAD grafts. The patient was very agitated during the procedure and
   the procedure was aborted. The patient returned to that cath lab and
   had a PROMUS placed in his LIMA. The patient is currently chest pain
   free and has been off NTG drip.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily

   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Uptitrate metoprolol tartrate (currently at 37.5 [**Hospital1 7**])
   - Consider adding low dose ACE inhibitor if pressures tolerate
   #. Respiratory failure: Unclear etiology. The patient was intubated on
   [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and low grade fever.
   The patient had a CT of the chest which demonstrated LLL pneumonia with
   bilateral pleural effusions. He was started on vancomycin and cefepime
   with a plan for an 8 day course. The patient was extubated on [**2182-1-27**].
   Put on BiPAP and tolerated with well. Was weaned to 50% FM and is
   currently oxygenating well. Patient is hypercarbic but with stable pH
   which means it may be chronic. Currently ABG appear stable but patient
   requiring large amounts of supplemental O2. Will continue to evaluated.
   CVP measured yesterday which was ~7 (although in context of single
   measurement is relatively meaningless).
   - continue IV vancomycin day 7, cefepime day 7 (plan for 8 day course)
   - continue frequent ABGs
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   - consider further diuresis if
   #. Sinus tachycardia: Unclear etiology. The patient had fluid challenge
   and pRBCs without clear any change in heart rate or blood pressure.
   Differential includes hypotension, PE, beta blocker withdrawal,
   hypoxia, fever, anxiety/agitation, hyperthyroidism, ischemia/MI, heart
   failure, chronic pulmonary disease. The patinet has a relatively low
   CVP but also did not respond to fluid challenges. Patient was
   anticoagulated and thus shouldn't have PE. ABG show patient isn't
   hypoxemic. No current fever. No history of hyperthyroidism or ongoing
   ischemia or MI. No history of pulmonary disease. Front runners include
   beta blocker withdrawal, anxiety/agitation and heart failure. Recent
   echo with maintained systolic function. Restarting beta blocker today.
   Will do best to control delirium and agitation with normal precautions.
   - minimize delirium
   - uptitrate metoprolol 37.5mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - continue tele
   - consider fluid challenge

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires large amounts of supplemental oxygen. He has a history of pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions, which can worsen his respiratory status.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of NSTEMI and underwent cardiac catheterization, which demonstrated occlusion of SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He may be at risk for cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or myocardial infarction.
* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is 140/66 mmHg, with a CVP of 5 mmHg. He may be at risk for hemodynamic instability, particularly if his fluid status changes or if he develops cardiac complications.
* Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions, which can increase his risk of infection. He may also be at risk for infection from his indwelling catheters.
* Delirium: The patient is experiencing delirium, which can worsen his respiratory status and increase his risk of cardiac complications.
* Malnutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeds, which may not be adequate to meet his nutritional needs. He may be at risk for malnutrition, particularly if he has a prolonged hospital stay.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and to improve his overall condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   82M with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, presented to OSH with NSTEMI
   c/b respiratory failure requiring intubation, pna on abx, agitation and
   sinus tachycardia, now s/p PROMUS to LIMA.
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient presented to an outside hospital with angina
   and troponin elevation. No EKG from OSH. Likely NSTEMI given EKG at
   [**Hospital1 19**]. Serum troponin at admission of 0.04. The patient underwent
   cardiac catheterization which demonstrated occlusion of SVG-OM1 and
   LIMA-LAD grafts. The patient was very agitated during the procedure and
   the procedure was aborted. The patient returned to that cath lab and
   had a PROMUS placed in his LIMA. The patient is currently chest pain
   free and has been off NTG drip.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily
   - Clopidogrel 75mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Continue metoprolol tartrate 37.5mg TID
   - Consider adding low dose ACE inhibitor if pressures tolerate
   #. Respiratory failure: Unclear etiology. The patient was intubated on
   [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and low grade fever.
   The patient had a CT of the chest which demonstrated LLL pneumonia with
   bilateral pleural effusions. He was started on vancomycin and cefepime
   with a plan for an 8 day course. The patient was extubated on [**2182-1-27**].
   Put on BiPAP and tolerated with well. Was weaned to 50% FM and is
   currently oxygenating well. Patient is hypercarbic but with stable pH
   which means it may be chronic. Currently ABG appear stable but patient
   requiring large amounts of supplemental O2. Will continue to evaluated.
   CVP measured yesterday which was ~7 (although in context of single
   measurement is relatively meaningless).
   - continue IV vancomycin day 8, cefepime day 8 (plan for 8 day course)
   - d/c antibiotics after todays dose
   - continue frequent ABGs
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   #. Sinus tachycardia: Unclear etiology. The patient had fluid challenge
   and pRBCs without clear any change in heart rate or blood pressure.
   Differential includes hypotension, PE, beta blocker withdrawal,
   hypoxia, fever, anxiety/agitation, hyperthyroidism, ischemia/MI, heart
   failure, chronic pulmonary disease. The patinet has a relatively low
   CVP but also did not respond to fluid challenges. Patient was
   anticoagulated and thus shouldn't have PE. ABG show patient isn't
   hypoxemic. No current fever. No history of hyperthyroidism or ongoing
   ischemia or MI. No history of pulmonary disease. Front runners include
   beta blocker withdrawal, anxiety/agitation and heart failure. Recent
   echo with maintained systolic function. Restarting beta blocker today.
   Will do best to control delirium and agitation with normal precautions.
   - minimize delirium
   - discontinue lines as possible
   - continue tele
   - consider fluid challenge today
   - consider eval for PE
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on
   [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on
   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was weaned.  Currently stable pressures.
   - consider transfusion or IVF bolus if evidence of hypoperfusion
 none
   at this time
   - keep even fluid balance today
   - start metoprolol tartrate today
   # Agitation/Mental status changes/CVA's/Hx of TIA: Patient's cardiac
   catheterization aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to
   significant doses of Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital
   records, patient has been confused and agitated since his
   hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. At home, however, his wife states that he
   is not confused, but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As
   patient has been attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is
   not fully oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary
   process appears to be agitation with some minor component of
   dementia/delirium. Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may
   have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Normal metabolic
   work-up as an inpatient. CT head on [**1-24**] demonstrated a small lacunar
   infarct of indeterminate age, so neurology was consulted. Neuro finds
   Small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular
   territories, suggesting a proximal source (heart or the aorta). This
   CVA may be complicating already complex delirium and dementia picture.
   - consider carotid u/s per neuro recs
   - f/u hemoglobin A1C
   - F/U Neurology recs
   - F/U Psych recs
   - 4 bed rail restraint, 2 ext restraints
 pulling at lines
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes as possible
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH. Increased
   dose [**1-29**] restarting feeding.  Home Gabapentin held.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Now is outside
   window for EtOH withdrawal. Will need monitoring for benzo withdrawal.
   - SW consult  when mental status improves
   #. HLD:

   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.
   - Continue to observe

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and EtOH abuse, who presented to the emergency department with NSTEMI and respiratory failure requiring intubation. He was found to have occlusion of SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, and a PROMUS was placed in his LIMA. He is currently chest pain-free and off NTG drip.

The patient has multiple comorbidities, including acute on chronic systolic CHF, sinus tachycardia, and agitation with possible dementia and delirium. He has a small lacunar infarct on his CT head, suggesting a proximal source of the infarct. He is also at risk for benzodiazepine withdrawal due to his EtOH abuse.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.5C
* Heart rate: 94 bpm
* Blood pressure: 121/80 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths/min
* SpO2: 94%

The patient's laboratory results are:

* WBC: 6.0
* Hct: 26.5
* Plt: 275 K/uL
* Cr: 1.0
* TCO2: 33
* Glucose: 146 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 15.3/35.6/1.3, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 38/3/0.11, Lactic Acid: 0.7 mmol/L, Ca++: 9.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 2.7 mg/dL

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue IV vancomycin and cefepime for 8 days
* D/C antibiotics after today's dose
* Continue frequent ABGs
* Wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
* Consider adding low-dose ACE inhibitor if pressures tolerate
* Restart metoprolol tartrate today
* Consider transfusion or IVF bolus if evidence of hypoperfusion
* Keep even fluid balance today
* Start metoprolol tartrate today
* Consider carotid u/s per neuro recs
* F/U hemoglobin A1C
* F/U Neurology recs
* F/U Psych recs
* 4 bed rail restraint, 2 ext restraints
* Frequent reorientation
* Minimize lines & tubes as possible

Potential medical complications:

* Pneumonia: The patient's CXR shows bibasilar atelectatic changes without definite acute focal pneumonia, but he is still at risk for developing pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient has a central line and is receiving antibiotics, which increases his risk for developing sepsis.
* Bleeding: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy and has a high risk of bleeding.
* Heart failure: The patient has a history of CHF and is at risk for developing heart failure due to his underlying condition and medications.
* Dementia: The patient has a history of dementia and is at risk for developing further cognitive decline.
* Delirium: The patient has a history of delirium and is at risk for developing further episodes of delirium.
* Benzodiazepine withdrawal: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse and is at risk for developing benzodiazepine withdrawal.
* Infection: The patient has a central line and is at risk for developing an infection.

   82M with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, presented to OSH with NSTEMI
   c/b respiratory failure requiring intubation, pna on abx, agitation and
   sinus tachycardia, now s/p PROMUS to LIMA.
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient presented to an outside hospital with angina
   and troponin elevation. No EKG from OSH. Likely NSTEMI given EKG at
   [**Hospital1 19**]. Serum troponin at admission of 0.04. The patient underwent
   cardiac catheterization which demonstrated occlusion of SVG-OM1 and
   LIMA-LAD grafts. The patient was very agitated during the procedure and
   the procedure was aborted. The patient returned to that cath lab and
   had a PROMUS placed in his LIMA. The patient is currently chest pain
   free and has been off NTG drip.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily
   - Clopidogrel 75mg daily

   - Consider adding low dose ACE inhibitor if pressures tolerate
   #. Respiratory failure: Unclear etiology. The patient was intubated on
   [**1-23**] in context of worsening respiratory status and low grade fever.
   The patient had a CT of the chest which demonstrated LLL pneumonia with
   bilateral pleural effusions. He was started on vancomycin and cefepime
   with a plan for an 8 day course. The patient was extubated on [**2182-1-27**].
   Put on BiPAP and tolerated with well. Was weaned to 50% FM and is
   currently oxygenating well. Patient is hypercarbic but with stable pH
   which means it may be chronic. Currently ABG appear stable but patient
   requiring large amounts of supplemental O2. Will continue to evaluated.
   CVP measured yesterday which was ~7 (although in context of single
   measurement is relatively meaningless).
   - continue IV vancomycin day 8, cefepime day 8 (plan for 8 day course)
   - d/c antibiotics after todays dose
   - continue frequent ABGs
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   #. Sinus tachycardia: Unclear etiology. The patient had fluid challenge
   and pRBCs without clear any change in heart rate or blood pressure.
   Differential includes hypotension, PE, beta blocker withdrawal,
   hypoxia, fever, anxiety/agitation, hyperthyroidism, ischemia/MI, heart
   failure, chronic pulmonary disease. The patinet has a relatively low
   CVP but also did not respond to fluid challenges. Patient was
   anticoagulated and thus shouldn't have PE. ABG show patient isn't
   hypoxemic. No current fever. No history of hyperthyroidism or ongoing
   ischemia or MI. No history of pulmonary disease. Front runners include
   beta blocker withdrawal, anxiety/agitation and heart failure. Recent
   echo with maintained systolic function. Restarting beta blocker today.
   Will do best to control delirium and agitation with normal precautions.
   - minimize delirium
   - continue tele
   - consider fluid challenge today
   - consider eval for PE
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**], but this is not the best study for EF.
   Patient with persistent fluid overload on admission, but he was not
   pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac catheterization. On transfer,
   patient demonstrates mild respiratory distress and O2 requirement,
   limited clinical exam suggests fluid overload. Received IV Lasix on
   transfer with good UOP, but was fluid overloaded as of [**1-23**] AM. TTE on
   [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on
   [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.  On [**1-26**], he remained pressor dependent, but
   levophed was weaned.  Currently stable pressures.
   - consider transfusion or IVF bolus if evidence of hypoperfusion

   significant doses of Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital

   hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. At home, however, his wife states that he
   is not confused, but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As
   patient has been attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is

   process appears to be agitation with some minor component of
   dementia/delirium. Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may
   have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Normal metabolic

   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most

   Assessment and Plan
   82M with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, presented to OSH with NSTEMI
   c/b respiratory failure requiring intubation, pna on abx, agitation and
   sinus tachycardia, now s/p PROMUS to LIMA.
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient presented to an outside hospital with angina
   and troponin elevation. No EKG from OSH. Likely NSTEMI given EKG at
   [**Hospital1 19**]. Serum troponin at admission of 0.04. The patient underwent
   cardiac catheterization which demonstrated occlusion of SVG-OM1 and
   LIMA-LAD grafts. The patient was very agitated during the procedure and
   the procedure was aborted. The patient returned to that cath lab and
   had a PROMUS placed in his LIMA. The patient is currently chest pain
   free.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily
   - Clopidogrel 75mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Continue metoprolol tartrate 37.5mg TID
   - continue lisinopril 2.5mg daily.
   #. Respiratory distress
 patient had bibasilar crackles, was volume up
   yesterday and is complaining of shortness of breath.  Patient has no
   further evidence of pneumonia on CXR.
   - vancomycin and cefipime discontinued yesterday.
   - CXR this AM
   - furosemide 40mg IV today.
   - wean off O2 as tolerated to keep SaO2 > 90%
   #. Sinus tachycardia: Unclear etiology. Patient may have been
   hypovolemic before, but is now volume up.  Rate is now improved.
   - continue on metoprolol as above.
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: TTE on [**1-23**] showed EF 30-35% with
   global hypokinesis. His Right heart cath on [**1-25**] had a PCWP of 15.
   - furosemide as above.
   # Agitation/Mental status changes/CVA's/Hx of TIA: Patient's cardiac
   catheterization aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to
   significant doses of Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital
   records, patient has been confused and agitated since his
   hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. At home, however, his wife states that he
   is not confused, but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As
   patient has been attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is
   not fully oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary
   process appears to be agitation with some minor component of
   dementia/delirium. Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may
   have some component of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Normal metabolic
   work-up as an inpatient. CT head on [**1-24**] demonstrated a small lacunar
   infarct of indeterminate age, so neurology was consulted. Neuro finds
   Small bihemispheric subacute infarcts involving multiple vascular
   territories, suggesting a proximal source (heart or the aorta). This
   CVA may be complicating already complex delirium and dementia picture.
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes as possible
   - Discontinue foley, replace with condom catheter.
   - attempt to place peripheral IV, discontinue triple lumen.
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH. Increased
   dose [**1-29**] restarting feeding.  Home Gabapentin held.
   - NPH 24u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal. Now is outside
   window for EtOH withdrawal. Will need monitoring for benzo withdrawal.
   -          SW consult  when mental status improves
   -          Continue thiamine, folic acid.
   #. HLD:
   - Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
    #. GERD:
   - Lansoprazole 30mg daily
   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.
   - Continue to observe
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nectar thick liquids
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin sliding scale and NPH 24/20
   Lines:

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and presented to the emergency department with non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and respiratory failure. He was intubated and received antibiotics, but his antibiotics were discontinued due to no evidence of pneumonia. The patient has been experiencing agitation, sinus tachycardia, and acute on chronic systolic heart failure. He has also been diagnosed with small bihemispheric subacute infarcts, likely due to a proximal source (heart or aorta), which may be complicating his delirium and dementia picture.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Continued cardiac arrhythmias
	* Heart failure exacerbation
	* Cardiac tamponade
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia
	* Respiratory failure
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
3. Neurological complications:
	* Increased agitation and aggression
	* Delirium and dementia progression
	* Stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) recurrence
4. Metabolic complications:
	* Hyperglycemia
	* Hypoglycemia
	* Electrolyte imbalance
5. Infection complications:
	* Catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI)
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
	* Line sepsis
6. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding
	* Nausea and vomiting
	* Abdominal distension
7. Endocrine complications:
	* Hyperglycemic hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome (HHNS)
	* Hypoglycemic coma

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and EtOH abuse, who presented to the hospital with NSTEMI and respiratory failure requiring intubation. He has undergone cardiac catheterization and has been treated with antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, and has been weaned off vasoactive medications. He has a history of confusion, agitation, and delirium, and has been diagnosed with a small lacunar infarct on CT head.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he requires large amounts of supplemental oxygen. He has persistent low lung volumes and bibasilar atelectatic changes on chest x-ray.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of NSTEMI and has undergone cardiac catheterization. He has a small lacunar infarct on CT head, which may be complicating his delirium and dementia picture.
3. Sepsis: The patient has been treated with antibiotics for pneumonia, but his blood cultures are pending. He has a fever and is receiving anticoagulation therapy, which may increase his risk of bleeding complications.
4. Delirium: The patient has a history of confusion, agitation, and delirium, and has been diagnosed with a small lacunar infarct on CT head. He requires frequent reorientation and has been placed on bed rails to prevent falls.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a history of GERD and is receiving lansoprazole therapy. He has also been diagnosed with a small bowel obstruction, which may require surgical intervention.
6. Renal Complications: The patient has a history of kidney disease and is receiving diuretic therapy. He may require further monitoring and treatment for his kidney function.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient has a history of EtOH withdrawal and has been diagnosed with a small lacunar infarct on CT head. He may require further monitoring and treatment for his neurological status.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's delirium and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal status and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
7. Consider consulting with a neurologist to further evaluate the patient's small lacunar infarct and to develop a plan for his further care.
